reviewText: Just got through watching the DVD.Holy crap! Talk about more bang for the buck!Don't know where to start. First the band sounds fantastic. They sound great together, they're having fun and it cooks! The mix is sweet and clean, the songs sound tight and ALIVE! With eyes closed and no crowd noise, you'd still know that you're hearing a concert recording.Second, they seem to really enjoy playing the music. Some of the stage banter seems a little forced, but I think that it's more the band just being the band rather than pandering to the crowd.And they're excited to be in front of a loving, happy, insane, bordering on maniacal audience. Just look at how these guys dig performing.The look of the show is amazing. The stage is just what the doctor ordered, a spectacle. From the tent to the pyro to the "added performers", it's a nuthouse! It looks like what a concert should be and after viewing it I wished that I was at the thing.And one last thing. Parts of it are like watching "Girls Gone Wild". Not a bad thing here. These "gentlemen" love their chickies and want to make sure that EVERYBODY gets a chance to share the enthusiasm.All in all a great DVD that could've easily cost more. The Disc 2 stuff is all well and good, but the concert is the thing.This reminds me of what a concert should be, a bunch of people seeing an amazing show, hearing a great band, and seeing what could possibly be,"The Greatest Show in the Universe"
summary: why does the negative review get to lead off?

reviewText: I give Mötley Crüe alot of credit in being able to rebrand themselves into classic kick a** party rock band. This concert  was and has been one of the best rock shows I have ever been to( around 70 or so). I am a big van halen fan, and I thought their reunion tour with Roth was good, I think Crüe put on a much better show here, and there 2011 tour was as good but desperately shorter.
summary: I dare say, perhaps the best  resurrected of all 80s band

reviewerName: David W. Doppes "Horror god of C-bus"
reviewText: This dvd is loaded with great Crue songs spaning most of their career. I like how the beginning of the concert was front loaded with the early toons and worked its way towards the more recent hits. As I lifelong fan of the band, I only wish that they had included more songs from "Generation swine" and the self titled "Motley crue" cd with Corabi on vocals. I know this would not play with Vince Neil, but the fans may want to hear the heaviest crue songs of all. Like I said, I am a lifelong fan and can enjoy any setlist they come up with.One reviewer here thought that 80% of the show was in red, its funny but I must have gotten a completely different copy of the show. The band is very clear and visible and if you have ever been to a concert in your life you would know that there are stage lights on. Don't listen to a concert virgins review, feel very confident on buying a dvd that has the band - including Vince Neil running on all 8 cylinders. Great show, great extra features and most important a cohesive Motley Crue again without any bad feelings within the band and you can really sense it here.
summary: A great dvd! Regardless of other blind reviewers

reviewText: In 2005 all the original members of Motley Crue reunited for a highly successful tour as documented on this Bluray release. Carnival of Sins captures one of these concerts as well as you can on video. I caught this show at the All State Arena in Rosemont, IL in March of 2005 and again in February 2006 at Roberts Stadium in Evansville, IN and I was as blown away buy this disc as I was at both shows. Everyone is firing on all cylinders, even Vince, who doesn't always handle the vocals that great, but here he is in top form. All the hits are played as well as many fan favorites from Too Fast for Love and Shout at the Devil. Yes this disc is rated R and has foul language and nudity. What do you expect, this is a Motley Crude concert.
summary: The best Crue video there is!

reviewText: Carnival Of Sins is just plain awesome.  The DVD is of such high quality and the production of the show itself is top notch professional.  The Crue are at their absolute best on this DVD.  I missed this tour back in 2005-2006, but I made up for it by going to the Crue Fest in the summer of '08.  Comparing that concert with this DVD, this DVD and tour were a little bit better, even though I'm judging a DVD vs. a live show I attended.  For one thing, the whole Carnival Of Sins concept was just perfect.  That is vintage Motley Crue.  This theme really brings out the true attitude that is Motley Crue.  The clowns, the dancers on stage, the pyrotechnics, the big top, fire breathers, the mad scientist solo by Nikki Sixx, the Tommy Cam, the trapeze drum solo by Tommy Lee...this DVD has it all, not to mention a great lineup of songs that the band played.  The Crue played a lot of songs on this tour that fans have been wanting them to play live for eons.  Examples:  Ten Seconds To Love, Red Hot, On With The Show, Too Young To Fall In Love, and Louder Than Hell.  This DVD is highly entertaining and will hold your attention from start to finish.  There is not a moment to be missed.There is also a DVD of Bonus Features, including Inside The Big Top "A Motley Documentary," Motley Crue's Greatest *its, Meet & Greet, Disaster! The Movie, and Blow It up.  There are also music videos.  I don't want to give away too much.  Buy this, and you'll be thoroughly entertained by one of the greatest rock bands ever.
summary: Let the mayhem begin
Title: N/A

reviewText: Based on what I have seen and heard this LOOKS and SOUNDS fantastic.  Yeah, the camera shots are active and change fast... but much of the concert is packed with toughness and adrenaline, it actually makes some sense that the shots match it in being active as well.  Sound-wise, this is the best the Crue have ever sounded live... this looks to me like a must own DVD.  If you are looking for a DVD to give you an example of suspect quality... check out the new Twisted Sister one... now that one looks and sounds cheap and sloppy.  This one looks like a gem... the only negative I see is its not out for another 2 months.  Final thoughts, boy is it good having Tommy back... the drumming is excellent and it really adds so much to the songs.  Vince is sounding better than he has in 20 years... and the guitar sound on this DVD is monsterously good... compare it to the Lewd Crued and Tatooed DVD of a few years back and you will really see how much better this version is!!!  Its nice to see another band and not just KISS putting on a show that is actually worthy of the price of modern concert tickets.
summary: WOW!!

reviewText: I attended this concert tour in June and this DVD was nearly identical. It was high energy and a strong performance by the band. They all rocked. Vince wasn't awesome on the lyrics but still gets the job done well enough to enjoy it. My only dissappointment with this concert/DVD was the '97 Shout at the Devil version used, which is the faster version that isn't as good in my opinion as original, but still cool. This DVD captures as much of that concert's feeling as possible. I was so hoping that they would release a video of this tour because this was a fabulous concert and great to have on DVD. This and KISS in concert are my favorite rock concerts ever. They really put forth some effort to please the crowd! I have the Crue's video collection DVD too, but if I had to pick one, this '05 would definitely be the one I'd buy. You will love it.
summary: Exactly what I wanted from '05 tour

reviewText: I watched the released Motley Crue DVD preview video clips and they are pretty bad. I love Motley Crue and have seen them twice this 2005 tour. I was really hoping the DVD would be better. In the DVD preview videos, the picture is not very clear, with significant excess color saturation and poor balance. Further the audio on several of the songs is very muddled and of general poor quality.I also am sick and tired of the artsy fartsy approach of all the moving and flashing nanosecond camera shots. It's just plain stupid. It's not how you watch a concert live, and is extremely annoying and distracting on the video.Clear Channel Entertainment (CCE), who are promoting the Motley Crue '05 Tour and produced, along with distributing, this new DVD get a big fat F. Can CCE do anything right?It should further be noted that this Motley Crue DVD was filmed in both Grand Rapids and Peoria, and is a compilation of the two concerts. It was originally to be filmed at Motley Crue's concert in San Antonio, Texas, where Clear Channel's corporate offices are located.
summary: Very Disappointing Live Video DVD
Title: N/A

reviewText: Motley Crue are one of the party metal survivors of the 80's, a band so in love with the celebration of decadence that their popularity has actually weathered the storm of the 90's fun police generations. This live documentation of their 2005 tour extravaganza is actually one concert DVD that lives up to it's blurb. For this visual and musical feast is very much an excellent purchase, in fact I'd go so far as to say it's pretty much an essential buy for any fan of the band, even lapsed ones.My reasons for this statement are;Firstly the quality of the package. The production qualities are good, the multiple camera angles blend together well and each band member gets a fair share of the attention, and the crowd are also given a lot of camera time as the director Hamish Hamilton has used the crowd participation shots to make this a very inclusive feeling gig. This emphasises the human factor and allows the energy of the event to seep through your sound system and it really is a masterstroke of live DVD production that a two dimensional screen can appear to transmit this much energy.Secondly apart from some rather predictable stage banter the band are on top form. Now I've no idea how much mini-disc is present here or how many overdubs but having seen this tour on it's Australian leg the band sounded pretty good and so perhaps this is very close to what the audience on the night actually heard, and that deserves credit.Further the band have played to their strengths yet still found time to slip in a couple of their newer tunes and it's this blend of tunes from across their catalogue that will keep long term fans happy here. Not to mention the massive event of the thing - the stage production here is bigger than Ben Hur with explosions, a great light show, more explosions, trapeze artists/dancers, a midget, a road crew that gets involved during the encore and some more explosions. Not to mention the intro video that the band played prior to going on each night during the tour which is genuinely amusing and not solely a few clichés of toilet humour - this is definitely a band that can laugh at itself.More value is added by the second disc which while not earth shattering does certainly add to your understanding of just how massive an undertaking this tour was. Some of the figures bandied about in relation to catering requirements etc. is truly disturbing in a way. All In The Name of Rock `n' Roll indeed...And it's this attention to quality in everything from their stage production, the quality of the spectacle and the desire to add even more value via the second disc of curios that really helps to underscore perhaps why Motley Crue experienced somewhat of a revival of fortunes during the mid noughties - I mean how many bands put on a show like this anymore? My mind boggles at what the insurance premiums for the stage show must of been.All up a great buy for Motley fans, pretty darn good for general party metal fans too given that this is pretty much the quintessential party metal band performing the quintessential party metal concert.
summary: Almost as many party metal hits as explosions. The full five stars.

reviewText: The Crue must not have gotten the memo. You know...the one that says, "1) Music DVD's should be produced to the highest standards. 2) The musical performances within should represent the talent that made the studio recorded CDs sell. 3) Theatrics are very cool too, as long as you can pull them off without deterioration in the quality of the music."Let's break it down then:1 - "Music DVD's should be produced to the highest standards." - The picture quality in Carnival of Sins is horrible. For about 80% of the DVD the stage seems to either be bathed in red light or it's a strange effect that the producers for some reason thought would be an enhancement. This predominant "red effect" makes for a mostly unclear viewing experience, and ruins the illusion of having a front row seat to the show; I felt like I was just sitting on my couch watching a DVD.The sound is okay. You get your choice between Dolby Stereo, Dolby 5.1 or DTS. But the mix is way below average. Vince's mic is either way down (for good reason...I'll get to that in a sec) or the producer's were novices. Which leads to the notion that the mix is only as good as the performances.2 - "The musical performances within should represent the talent that made the studio recorded CDs sell." - Nicki is on. Mick's on. Tommy's on. Vince...CLUNK. I have watched some very awesome DVD performances by some "old-timers" like Kiss (Rock the Nation Live), Rush (R30) and Judas Priest (Rising in the East), and these guys prior to hitting the stage for their respective DVD recordings all must have huddled and committed to each other to go out and play the music true to the studio versions of the songs. So it can be done. On the other hand, Vince Neil in Carnival is mostly unclear and often sings only the second half of a lyric (does he think no one notices that?). Vince's poor singing turned this from a potentially exciting release into a DVD documentation of how badly the studio versions of some great songs can be minimized to mere background music to an attempt at profound theatrics. Which leads perfectly into point #3.3 - "Theatrics are very cool too, as long as you can pull them off without deterioration in the quality of the music." - Tommy is in Kabuki face. Nicki actually looks good. Mick looks like a cross between Boris Karloff's portrayal of The Mummy and Alice Cooper wearing Slash's hat. And Vince looks like some knucklehead from the audience that came up to do the singing (sounds like it too). There were midgets, girl on girl action and scantily clad women doing aerobics. Between songs there was a lot of the "F" word (perhaps The Crue heard "profound theatrics" and thought that meant use profanity?). There's a "show your breasts" segment (which the clearly hired help willingly obliges), and overall the reddish, unclear picture makes the whole show a mess.This DVD is truly a Carnival of Sins. I was really looking forward to viewing this show; the song choices are terrific. I am a big fan of Motley's music, but (obviously) I was disappointed in the production quality and performance effort that went into this release.Rated R for Ridiculous.
summary: Motley Crue Must Not Have Gotten The Memo
Title: N/A

reviewText: Motley Crue's new "Carnival of Sins-Live" DVD is the best Motley Crue DVD there is--by far.This is a two disc DVD,and while it is not perfect,it is really good and solid. It opens up with a very funny and short cartoon on how Motley Crue got back together,and once you have seen the cartoon for the show/Motley Crue's getting back together and going on a tour(which Motley used on all of their shows;I saw The Crue at their concert at Conseco Fieldhouse in Indianapolis)the concert on this DVD opens up with a great version of "Shout At The Devil '97"(note that the back of the DVD specifies it as the original SATD,but if you are a die hard Motley fan,you will notice that The Crue are playing Shout '97 at the beginning of this concert that is on this DVD,NOT the original Shout). This whole concert finds Motley Crue playing (mostly)their hits/fan favorites from the 80's("Girls,Girls,Girls","Dr. Feelgood","Live Wire","Ten Seconds To Love","Home Sweet Home",etc.)with the addition of two Motley songs from the 90's("Primal Scream" and half of the ballad "Glitter"),their two new original songs off of their "Red,White,and Crue" anthology album("If I Die Tommorow" and "Sick Love Song")as well as two cover songs("Helter Skelter" and "Anarchy In The U.K."). Note the fact that this concert was made as a film,it looks like a concert that is a movie,and while I would have just preferred a concert,the whole movie/concert concept into one theme was a really good idea that works here. The camera does switch back from the band to the audience too often at the beginning of this concert/film but gets better at focusing on the band towards the end of the DVD,and the live performances of the songs on here are really good(Motley Crue were being honest when they said that they still do have energy left in them)! Nikki Sixx's bass solo and Tommy Lee's drum solo are quite impressive,and not only are Motley Crue able to keep this DVD entertaining by not only playing most of their best material live and doing a great job at it,the midget onstage(who is sort of a mini Vince Neil)is hillarious and is a good supplement to the whole concert/film. It is also pretty cool to see aerialists on stage accompanying "The World's Most Infamous Rock Band"(especially during the live performances of "Girls,Girls,Girls" and "Ten Seconds To Love"). This whole concert/film is pretty cool,but the highlights for me would have to be 1)Nikki Sixx dressed like a mad scientist while he is doing his bass solo,2)Tommy Lee's drum solo and his "fan cam"(wait until you see that),and 3)seeing the guys in Motley Crue dressed as military guys while they perform "Helter Skelter" and "Anarachy In The U.K."(which are the last two songs they performed for the concert that is on this DVD).There are a lot of bonus feautures on disc two of this DVD,which made me really happy. There is a documentary on Motley Crue's 2005 tour,a behind the scenes look at when Tommy Lee brings his "fan cam" onstage(I'd tell you about it,but it is something that will seem more funny if you buy this DVD and see it for yourself),a short,hillarious,cartoon movie called "Meet & Greet'Disaster!The Movie'Blow It Up" on Motley Crue,and there are three new music videos here. These videos are the time lapse view video for "On With The Show","If I Die Tommorow",and the "clean" video for "Sick Love Song". All of these videos are very cool(especially the time lapse video for "On With The Show",which is both very cool and very creative)and while I am a little dissaspointed that BOTH the clean AND the unclean video for "Sick Love Song" are NOT on this DVD(I am glad to have the SLS video here;it is just there was an unclean video for SLS that you can see very far back on [...] point is that it would have helped Crue fans out to watch both the unclean and the clean video for SLS whenever they wanted to instead of going very far back on the Motley Crue website to see the unclean SLS video if they wanted to see it)but other than that,I am not complaining. I like getting to have loads of bonus feautures on disc two of this DVD and getting to see Vince,Nikki,Tommy,and Mick Mars all talk about this whole tour/DVD is really cool(Motley Crue are really the best band there is when it comes to leaving their fans happy). This DVD also has a nice poster that has pictures of Motley Crue from the COS tour accompanying it,which is nice to have here,and despite it's little flaws,this DVD is very awesome overall. Anyway,thank you for reading my review of this,have a great day,and don't forget....Motley Crue rules!!!!
summary: An awesome and excellent Motley Crue DVD
